Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support student participation in the Field of Dreams Conference, to be held in St. Louis, Missouri, from November 3-5 2017. The Field of Dreams conference is organized by the National Alliance for Doctoral Studies in the Mathematical Sciences (the Alliance), an organization whose goal is to increase the number of students from backgrounds underrepresented in the mathematical sciences who earn doctorates in those fields. Approximately 200 students will attend the conference, and about 75% of those will be underrepresented minorities. More details about the conference activities can be found at the conference website: https://mathalliance.org/2017-field-of-dreams-conference/

The conference coordinates with the Alliance's Facilitated Graduate Admissions Process (F-GAP), which has helped place approximately 65 Alliance Scholars in graduate programs each of the last three years. The conference is an essential part of a program to produce a more diverse professional mathematical workforce. The conference will feature scientific talks by prominent mathematical scientists, activities that assist faculty in mentoring practices, and events that help academic departments transform their cultures to be more supportive of student success.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2017 Field of Dreams Conference was held November 3-5, 2017, at the Renaissance Airport Hotel in St. Louis, MO. There were 338 conference participants: 181 undergraduate and terminal MS Alliance Scholars, 106 faculty mentors,36 Ph.D. students, and 15 participants were exhibitors, representatives of NSF Funded Math Science Institutes, Alliance Board members and Staff, and outside speakers.

We attach the agenda to the Final Report, and summarize some highlights. There were four major addresses during the meeting. On Friday, November 3, Rachel Levy, of Harvey Mudd College, delivered our 2nd annual Connections lecture, titled The BIG Math Network.  On Saturday November 4, The Math Sciences Lecture was given by Joseph Teran, UCLA, on Scientific Computing in the Movies and Beyond, and the annual Banquet Keynote address was delivered by Garakai Campbell, Morehouse College, titled The Changing Higher Education Landscape: One Mathematician Turned Administrator's View.  On Friday, November 3, we also had a Special Keynote address, delivered by Christine Darden, NASA retired (one of Margot Shutterly's Hidden Figures), titled On Their Shoulders.  A new feature for 2017 the Field of Dreams Conference  was nine short (20 minute) What Is... talks presented by representatives of NSF funded Math Sciences Institutes, each being a brief introduction to a topic in a mathematical science. The titles and speakers  for these nine talks can be viewed in the  agenda. Other important events at the conference included the Graduate School/Career/ Sumer Program Fair (Saturday afternoon), panels for students on various aspects of preparing for graduate school, and panels for faculty on mentoring practices. Following Dr. Darden's lecture there was a special panel featuring Dr. Darden, and two current NASA engineers.

The primary objective of this conference, as part of the work of the Alliance in general, is to produce more doctorates in the mathematical sciences among groups which are traditionally underrepresented in those fields. The conference supported by this award contributed to accomplishing that objective by exposing our predoctoral Alliance Scholars (70 to 80% of whom are underrepresented minorities) to the opportunities available to them in a broad range of disciplines in which their preparation in quantitative fields is desirable. The conference also plays an important role in F-GAP, a program which works to place our students into graduate programs where they can succeed. There were 109 participants in the 2017-18 F-GAP program, an increase of 6.8% over 2016-17. At the 2017 conference, 89 F-GAP students were in attendance, which was an increase of 9.8% over the previous year. Extrapolating from the survey responses we've received from this group, we expect about 85 F-GAP students were admitted to graduate programs in the mathematical sciences. Based on the outcomes of previous F-GAP cohorts, we expect their retention rate within these programs to be very high. During the Field of Dreams Conference F-GAP students consult one on one with their faculty facilitator, and have the opportunity to speak with representatives of graduate programs the student, facilitator, and undergraduate mentor, have determined are a good fit for the student's goals and academic background. We have identified 63 Ph.D.s received by students who were Alliance Predoctoral Scholars (i.e., were Alliance Scholars prior to entering a Ph.D. program).  None of these 63 degrees was earned by students in the F-GAP program, because the first F-GAP students entered Ph.D. programs in 2014.  So, we expect the first F-GAP Ph.D.s to be awarded in 2019, and thus expect the number of Alliance Scholar Ph.D.s to rise rapidly.
